[[Loève Prize]] (1997)
[[Fermat Prize]] (2005) }} '''Jean-François Le Gall''' (born 15 November 1959) is a [[France|French]] [[mathematician]] working in areas of [[probability theory]] such as [[Wiener process|Brownian motion]], [[Lévy process]]es, [[superprocess]]es and their connections with [[partial differential equation]]s, the Brownian snake, random trees, [[branching process]]es, stochastic coalescence and random planar maps. He received his Ph.D. in 1982 under the supervision of [[Marc Yor]].{{mathgenealogy|id=80792}}. He is currently professor at the [[University of Paris-Sud in Orsay]] and is a senior member of the Institut universitaire de France. He was elected to French academy of sciences, December 2013. He was awarded the [[Rollo Davidson Prize]] in 1986, the [[Loève Prize]] in 1997,[http://www.stat.berkeley.edu/administration/newsletter98.3/loeve.html Le Gall Receives Loève Prize], Steven N. Evans and Lucien Le Cam, Statistics Department, [[University of California, Berkeley]], retrieved 2010-02-15. and the [[Fermat Prize]] in 2005.[http://www.ams.org/notices/200602/people.pdf Mathematics People: Colmez and Le Gall Awarded Fermat Prize], Notices of the [[American Mathematical Society]], Volume 53, Number 2. 2006. He was the thesis advisor of at least 11 students including [[Wendelin Werner]]. ==Books== *Le Gall, Jean-François, ''Spatial branching processes, random snakes and partial differential equations''. Lectures in Mathematics ETH Zürich.
